[[File:STS-130 Endeavour flyaround 5.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[International Space Station]] in [[orbit]] around [[Earth]], February 2010. The ISS is in a '''micro-g environment'''.]]
The term '''micro-g environment''' (also '''µg''', often referred to by the term '''microgravity''') is more or less a synonym for ''[[weightlessness]]'' and ''zero-g'', but indicates that [[g-force]]s are not quite zero—just very small.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.jamesoberg.com/myth.html |title=Space myths and misconceptions – space flight |journal=[[Omni (magazine)|OMNI]] |date=May 1993 |volume=15 |number=7 |page=38ff}}<!-- alternate link: http://lab.machinecode.org/intricate/omni_magazine/Omni%20v15%20%237%20May%201993.html --></ref> The symbol for microgravity, ''µg'', was used on the insignias of [[Space Shuttle]] flights [[STS-87]] and [[STS-107]], because these flights were devoted to microgravity research in [[low Earth orbit]].
==Absence of gravity== A "stationary" micro-g environment<ref>Depending on distance, "stationary" is meant relative to Earth or the Sun.</ref> would require travelling far enough into deep space so as to reduce the effect of gravity by [[attenuation]] to almost zero. This is the simplest in conception, but requires traveling an enormous distance, rendering it most impractical. For example, to reduce the gravity of the Earth by a factor of one million, one needs to be at a distance of 6 million kilometers from the Earth, but to reduce the gravity of the Sun to this amount one has to be at a distance of 3.7 billion kilometers. (On Earth the gravity due to the rest of the [[Milky Way]] is already attenuated by a factor greater than one million, so we do not need to move away further from its [[Galactic Center|center]]{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}). Thus it is not impossible, but it has only been achieved so far by four [[interstellar probe]]s ([[Voyager 1]] and [[Voyager 2|2]] of the [[Voyager program]], and [[Pioneer 10]] and [[Pioneer 11|11]] of the [[Pioneer program]]<!-- [[New Horizons]] it's expected to do so in the near future-->) and they did not return to Earth. To reduce the gravity to one thousandth of that on Earth's surface, one needs to be at a distance of 200,000 km.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2 | Location !! colspan=3 | Gravity due to !! rowspan=2 | Total |- ! [[Earth]] !! [[Sun]] !! rest of [[Milky Way]] |- | Earth's surface || 9.81 m/s<sup>2</sup> || 6 mm/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup> = 6 mm/s/yr|| 9.81 m/s<sup>2</sup> |- | [[Low Earth orbit]] || 9 m/s<sup>2</sup> || 6 mm/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup>|| 9 m/s<sup>2</sup> |- | 200,000 km from Earth || 10 mm/s<sup>2</sup> || 6 mm/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup> || up to 12 mm/s<sup>2</sup> |- | {{val|6e6|u=km}} from Earth || 10 μm/s<sup>2</sup> || 6 mm/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup> || 6 mm/s<sup>2</sup> |- | {{val|3.7e9|u=km}} from Earth || 29 pm/s<sup>2</sup> || 10 μm/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup> || 10 μm/s<sup>2</sup> |- | [[Voyager 1]] ({{val|17e9|u=km}} from Earth) || 1 pm/s<sup>2</sup> || 500 nm/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup> || 500 nm/s<sup>2</sup> |- | 0.1 [[light-year]] from Earth || 400 am/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup> || 200 pm/s<sup>2</sup>|| up to 400 pm/s<sup>2</sup> |}
At a distance relatively close to Earth (less than 3000 km), gravity is only slightly reduced. As an object orbits a body such as the Earth, gravity is still attracting objects towards the Earth and the object is accelerated downward at almost 1g. Because the objects are typically moving laterally with respect to the surface at such immense speeds, the object will not lose altitude because of the curvature of the Earth. When viewed from an orbiting observer, other close objects in space appear to be floating because everything is being pulled towards Earth at the same speed, but also moving forward as the Earth's surface "falls" away below. All these objects are in free fall, not zero gravity.
Compare the [[Gravitational potential#Numerical values|gravitational potential at some of these locations]].
==Free fall== What remains is a micro-g environment moving in [[free fall]], i.e. there are no forces other than gravity acting on the people or objects in this environment. To prevent air drag making the free fall less perfect, objects and people can free-fall in a capsule that itself, while not necessarily in free fall, is accelerated as in free fall.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} This can be done by applying a force to compensate for air drag. Alternatively free fall can be carried out in space, or in a vacuum tower or shaft.
Two cases can be distinguished: Temporary micro-g, where after some time the Earth's surface is or would be reached, and indefinite micro-g.
A temporary micro-g environment exists in a [[drop tube]] (in a tower or shaft), a [[sub-orbital spaceflight]], e.g. with a [[sounding rocket]], and in an airplane such as used by [[NASA]]'s Reduced Gravity Research Program, aka the [[Vomit Comet]], and by the [[Zero Gravity Corporation]]. A temporary micro-g environment is applied for training of astronauts, for some experiments, for filming movies, and for recreational purposes.
A micro-g environment for an indefinite time, while also possible in a spaceship going to infinity in a parabolic or hyperbolic orbit, is most practical in an Earth orbit. This is the environment commonly experienced in the [[International Space Station]], [[Space Shuttle]], etc. While this scenario is the most suitable for scientific experimentation and commercial exploitation, it is still quite expensive to operate in, mostly due to launch costs.
==Tidal and inertial acceleration==
Objects in orbit are not perfectly weightless due to several effects:
*Effects depending on relative position in the spacecraft: **Because the force of gravity decreases with distance, objects with non-zero size will be subjected to a [[tidal force]], or a differential pull, between the ends of the object nearest and furthest from the Earth. (An extreme version of this effect is [[spaghettification]].) In a spacecraft in [[low Earth orbit]] (LEO), the [[centrifugal force]] is also greater on the side of the spacecraft furthest from the Earth. At a 400 km LEO altitude, the overall differential in g-force is approximately 0.384 μ''g''/m. <ref = name=conceptual>https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tqpqB5LPxygC&lpg=PA56&ots=pFOiNIwm6m&dq=microgravity%20tidal%20equations&pg=PA57#v=onepage&q=microgravity%20tidal%20equations&f=true Conceptual Design and Flight Simulation of Space Stations By Reinhold Bertrand</ref> ** "Floating" objects in a spacecraft in LEO are actually in independent orbits around the Earth. If two objects are placed side-by-side (relative to their direction of motion), they will be orbiting the Earth in different orbital planes. Since all orbital planes pass through the center of the earth, any two orbital planes intersect along a line. Therefore, two objects placed side-by-side (at any distance apart) will come together after one quarter of a revolution. If they are placed so they miss each other, they will oscillate past each other, with the same period as the orbit. This corresponds to an inward acceleration of 0.128 μ''g'' per meter horizontal distance from the center at 400 km altitude.<ref = name=conceptual/> If they are placed one ahead of the other in the same orbital plane, they will maintain their separation. If they are placed one above the other (at different radii from the center of the Earth), they will have different potential energies, so the size, eccentricity, and period of their orbits will be different, causing them to move in a complex looping pattern relative to each other.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Chandler, David|title=Weightlessness and Microgravity|journal=The Physics Teacher|date= May 1991|pages=312–13|url=http://www.lcurve.org/writings/PT-WeightlessnessAndMicrogravity.pdf|doi=10.1119/1.2343327|bibcode=1991PhTea..29..312C}}</ref> **Gravity between the spacecraft and an object within it may make the object slowly "fall" toward a more massive part of it. The acceleration is 0.007 μ''g'' for 1000 kg at 1 m distance. *Uniform effects (which could be compensated): **Though very thin, there is some air at orbital altitudes of 185 to 1,000 km. This atmosphere causes deceleration due to friction. This could be compensated by a small continuous thrust, but in practice the deceleration is only compensated from time to time, so the small g-force of this effect is not eliminated. **The effects of the [[solar wind]] and [[radiation pressure]] are similar, but directed away from the Sun. Unlike the effect of the atmosphere, it does not reduce with altitude.
==Commercial applications==
===Metal spheres=== In a [[shot tower]] (now obsolete), molten metal (such as [[lead]] or [[steel]]) was dripped through a sieve into free fall. With sufficient height (several hundred feet), the metal would be solid enough to resist impact (usually in a water bath) at the bottom of the tower. While the shot may have been slightly deformed by its passage through the air and by impact at the bottom, this method produced metal spheres of sufficient roundness to be used directly in [[shotgun]] shells or to be refined by further processing for applications requiring higher accuracy.
===High-quality crystals=== While not yet a commercial application, there has been interest in growing [[crystal]]s in micro-g, as in a [[space station]] or automated artificial [[satellite]], in an attempt to reduce crystal lattice defects.<ref>"[http://news.discovery.com/space/growing-crystals-in-zero-gravity-121227.htm Growing Crystals in Zero-Gravity]" News Article by [[Discovery Channel|Discovery]]</ref> Such defect-free crystals may prove useful for certain microelectronic applications and also to produce crystals for subsequent [[X-ray crystallography]].
<gallery> Image:Comparison2.jpg|Comparison of boiling of water under earth's gravity (1 g, left) and microgravity (right). The source of heat is in the lower part of the photograph. Image:Space Fire.jpg|A comparison between the combustion of a candle on [[Earth]] (left) and in a microgravity environment, such as that found on the [[ISS]] (right). Image:Crystals grown in microgravity.jpg|Protein crystals grown by American scientists on the Russian Space Station ''[[Mir]]'' in 1995.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=11541085|year=1996|author1=Koszelak|first1=S|title=Crystallization of biological macromolecules from flash frozen samples on the Russian Space Station Mir|journal=Biotechnology and Bioengineering|volume=52|issue=4|pages=449–58|last2=Leja|first2=C|last3=McPherson|first3=A|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0290(19961120)52:4<449::AID-BIT1>3.0.CO;2-P}}</ref> File:Insulin crystals comparison.jpg|Comparison of [[insulin]] crystals growth in outer space (left) and on Earth (right). </gallery>
== Health effects of the micro-g environment ==
===Space Motion Sickness=== [[File:Astronauts in weightlessness.jpg|thumb|288x288px|Six astronauts who had been in training at the Johnson Space Center for almost a year are getting a sample of a micro-g environment]] [[Space adaptation syndrome|Space Motion Sickness]] (SMS) is thought to be a subtype of [[motion sickness]] that plagues nearly half of all astronauts who venture into space.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weerts|first=Aurélie P.|last2=Vanspauwen|first2=Robby|last3=Fransen|first3=Erik|last4=Jorens|first4=Philippe G.|last5=Van de Heyning|first5=Paul H.|last6=Wuyts|first6=Floris L.|date=2014-06-01|title=Space Motion Sickness Countermeasures: A Pharmacological Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/asma/asem/2014/00000085/00000006/art00008|journal=Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine|volume=85|issue=6|pages=638–644|doi=10.3357/asem.3865.2014}}</ref> SMS, along with facial stuffiness from headward shifts of fluids, headaches, and back pain, is part of a broader complex of symptoms that comprise Space Adaptation Syndrome (SAS).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://humanresearchroadmap.nasa.gov/Evidence/medicalConditions/Space_Motion_Sickness_(Space_Adaptation).pdf|title=Space Motion Sickness (Space Adaptation)|last=|first=|date=June 15, 2016|website=NASA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 25, 2017}}</ref> SMS was first described in 1961 during the second orbit of the fourth manned spaceflight when the Cosmonaut, [[Gherman Titov]] aboard the [[Vostok 2]], described feeling disoriented with physical complaints mostly consistent with motion sickness. It is one of the most studied physiological problems of spaceflight but continues to pose a significant difficulty for many astronauts. In some instances, it can be so debilitating that astronauts must sit out from their scheduled occupational duties in space – including missing out on a spacewalk they have spent months training to perform.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=4270801&page=1|title=Illness keeps astronaut from spacewalk|last=|first=|date=February 12, 2008|website=ABCNews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 25, 2017}}</ref> In most cases, however, astronauts will work through the symptoms even with degradation in their performance.<ref name=":03">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/10.1007/978-3-319-32829-4|title=The Human Body and Weightlessness {{!}} SpringerLink|last=Thornton|first=William|last2=Bonato|first2=Frederick|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=32|language=en-gb|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-32829-4}}</ref>
Despite their experiences in some of the most rigorous and demanding physical maneuvers on earth, even the most seasoned astronauts may be affected by SMS, resulting in symptoms of severe [[nausea]], projectile [[vomiting]], [[Fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], malaise (feeling sick), and [[headache]].<ref name=":03" /> These symptoms may occur so abruptly and without any warning that space travelers may vomit suddenly without time to contain the emesis, resulting in strong odors and liquid within the cabin which may affect other astronauts.<ref name=":03" /> Symptoms typically last anywhere from one to three days upon entering weightlessness, but may recur upon reentry to Earth’s gravity or even shortly after landing. SMS differs from terrestrial motion sickness in that sweating and pallor are typically minimal or absent and gastrointestinal findings usually demonstrate absent bowel sounds indicating reduced [[gastrointestinal motility]].<ref name=":13">{{Cite book|title=Space Pharmacology|last=Wotring|first=V. E.|publisher=Springer|year=2012|isbn=978-1-4614-3396-5|location=Boston|pages=52}}</ref>
Even when the nausea and vomiting resolve, some central nervous system symptoms may persist which may degrade the astronaut’s performance.<ref name=":13" /> Graybiel and Knepton proposed the term “[[sopite syndrome]]” to describe symptoms of lethargy and drowsiness associated with motion sickness in 1976.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Graybiel|first=A.|last2=Knepton|first2=J.|date=August 1976|title=Sopite syndrome: a sometimes sole manifestation of motion sickness|journal=Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine|volume=47|issue=8|pages=873–882|issn=0095-6562|pmid=949309}}</ref> Since then, their definition has been revised to include “…a symptom complex that develops as a result of exposure to real or apparent motion and is characterized by excessive drowsiness, lassitude, lethargy, mild depression, and reduced ability to focus on an assigned task.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/262582074_Sopite_Syndrome_A_Revised_Definition|title=Sopite Syndrome: A Revised Definition (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-11-27}}</ref> Together, these symptoms may pose a substantial threat (albeit temporary) to the astronaut who must remain attentive to life and death issues at all times.
SMS is most commonly thought to be a disorder of the vestibular system that occurs when sensory information from the visual system (sight) and the proprioceptive system (posture, position of the body) conflicts with misperceived information from the semicircular canals and the otoliths within the inner ear. This is known as the ‘neural mismatch theory’ and was first suggested in 1975 by Reason and Brand.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/2073893|title=Motion sickness|last=T.|first=Reason, J.|date=1975|publisher=Academic Press|others=Brand, J. J.,|isbn=0125840500|location=London|oclc=2073893}}</ref> Alternatively, the fluid shift hypothesis suggests that weightlessness reduces the hydrostatic pressure on the lower body causing fluids to shift toward the head from the rest of the body. These fluid shifts are thought to increase cerebrospinal fluid pressure (causing back aches), intracranial pressure (causing headaches), and inner ear fluid pressure (causing vestibular dysfunction).<ref name="Heer 77–79">{{Cite journal|last=Heer|first=Martina|last2=Paloski|first2=William H.|title=Space motion sickness: Incidence, etiology, and countermeasures|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1566070206002141|journal=Autonomic Neuroscience|volume=129|issue=1–2|pages=77–79|doi=10.1016/j.autneu.2006.07.014|year=2006}}</ref>
Despite a multitude of studies searching for a solution to the problem of SMS, it remains an ongoing problem for space travel. Most non-pharmacological countermeasures such as training and other physical maneuvers have offered minimal benefit. Thornton and Bonato noted, “Pre- and inflight adaptive efforts, some of them mandatory and most of them onerous, have been, for the most part, operational failures.”<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/10.1007/978-3-319-32829-4|title=The Human Body and Weightlessness {{!}} SpringerLink|last=Thornton|first=William|last2=Bonato|first2=Frederick|language=en-gb|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-32829-4}}</ref> To date, the most common intervention is [[promethazine]], an injectable antihistamine with antiemetic properties, but sedation can be a problematic side effect.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.springer.com/us/book/9781461433958|title=Space Pharmacology {{!}} Virginia E. Wotring {{!}} Springer|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=59|language=en}}</ref> Other common pharmacological options include [[Metoclopramide|metaclopromide]], as well as oral and transdermal application of [[scopolamine]], but drowsiness and sedation are common side effects for these medications as well.<ref name="Heer 77–79"/>
===Musculoskeletal effects=== In the space (or microgravity) environment the effects of unloading varies significantly among individuals, with sex differences compounding the variability.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ploutz-Snyder|first=Lori|last2=Bloomfield|first2=Susan|last3=Smith|first3=Scott M.|last4=Hunter|first4=Sandra K.|last5=Templeton|first5=Kim|last6=Bemben|first6=Debra|date=2014-11-01|title=Effects of Sex and Gender on Adaptation to Space: Musculoskeletal Health|url=http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/jwh.2014.4910|journal=Journal of Women's Health|volume=23|issue=11|pages=963–966|doi=10.1089/jwh.2014.4910|issn=1540-9996}}</ref> Differences in mission duration, and the small sample size of astronauts participating in the same mission also adds to the variability to the [[musculoskeletal disorder]]s that are seen in space.<ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Narici|first=M. V.|last2=Boer|first2=M. D. de|date=2011-03-01|title=Disuse of the musculo-skeletal system in space and on earth|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00421-010-1556-x|journal=European Journal of Applied Physiology|language=en|volume=111|issue=3|pages=403–420|doi=10.1007/s00421-010-1556-x|issn=1439-6319}}</ref> In addition to muscle loss, microgravity leads to increased [[bone resorption]], decreased [[bone mineral density]], and increased fracture risks. Bone resorption leads to increased urinary levels of [[Calcium in biology|calcium]], which can subsequently lead to an increased risk of [[nephrolithiasis]].<ref name=":33">{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Scott M.|last2=Heer|first2=Martina|last3=Shackelford|first3=Linda C.|last4=Sibonga|first4=Jean D.|last5=Spatz|first5=Jordan|last6=Pietrzyk|first6=Robert A.|last7=Hudson|first7=Edgar K.|last8=Zwart|first8=Sara R.|title=Bone metabolism and renal stone risk during International Space Station missions|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S8756328215003658|journal=Bone|volume=81|pages=712–720|doi=10.1016/j.bone.2015.10.002|year=2015}}</ref>
In the first two weeks that the muscles are unloaded from carrying the weight of the human frame during space flight, whole muscle atrophy begins. Postural muscles contain more slow fibers, and are more prone to atrophy than non-postural muscle groups.<ref name=":23" /> The loss of muscle mass occurs because of imbalances in protein synthesis and breakdown. The loss of muscle mass is also accompanied by a loss of muscle strength, which was observed after only 2–5 days of spaceflight during the [[Soyuz 3|Soyuz-3]] and [[Soyuz 8|Soyuz-8]] missions.<ref name=":23" /> Decreases in the generation of contractile forces and whole muscle power have also been found in response to microgravity.
To counter the effects of microgravity on the musculoskeletal system, aerobic exercise is recommended. This often takes the form of in-flight cycling.<ref name=":23" /> A more effective regimen includes resistive exercises or the use of a penguin suit<ref name=":23" /> (contains sewn-in elastic bands to maintain a stretch load on antigravity muscles), centrifugation, and vibration.<ref name=":33" /> Centrifugation recreates Earth’s gravitational force on the space station, in order to prevent [[muscle atrophy]]. Centrifugation can be performed with centrifuges or by cycling along the inner wall of the space station.<ref name=":23" /> Whole body vibration has been found to reduce bone resorption through mechanisms that are unclear. Vibration can be delivered using exercise devices that use vertical displacements juxtaposed to a fulcrum, or by using a plate that oscillates on a vertical axis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Elmantaser|first=M.|last2=McMillan|first2=M.|last3=Smith|first3=K.|last4=Khanna|first4=S.|last5=Chantler|first5=D.|last6=Panarelli|first6=M.|last7=Ahmed|first7=S. F.|date=September 2012|title=A comparison of the effect of two types of vibration exercise on the endocrine and musculoskeletal system|journal=Journal of Musculoskeletal & Neuronal Interactions|volume=12|issue=3|pages=144–154|issn=1108-7161|pmid=22947546}}</ref> The use of [[Beta2-adrenergic agonist|beta-2 adrenergic agonists]] to increase muscle mass, and the use of essential amino acids in conjunction with resistive exercises have been proposed as pharmacologic means of combating muscle atrophy in space.<ref name=":23" />
Microgravity can also lead to height increases; in 2018 a Japanese astronout reported growing 2 centimetres in just three weeks of micro-gravity on board the [[International Space Station]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gizmodo.com/japanese-astronaut-concerned-after-growing-3-5-inches-t-1821910135 |title=Japanese Astronaut Concerned After Growing 3.5 Inches Taller in Three Weeks - Update: He Was Wrong |publisher=[[Gizmodo]] |accessdate=January 9, 2018}}</ref>
=== Cardiovascular effects === [[File:StationLIFE - Cardiovascular (January 2016).webm|thumb|569x569px|Astronaut Tracy Dyson talks about studies into cardiovascular health aboard the International Space Station.]] Next to the skeletal and muscular system, the cardiovascular system is less strained in weightlessness than on Earth and is de-conditioned during longer periods spent in space.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/0471263869.sst074/abstract|title=Encyclopedia of Space Science and Technology|last=Ramsdell|first=Craig D.|last2=Cohen|first2=Richard J.|date=2003|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|isbn=9780471263869|language=en|doi=10.1002/0471263869.sst074}}</ref> In a regular environment, gravity exerts a downward force, setting up a vertical hydrostatic gradient. When standing, some 'excess' fluid resides in vessels and tissues of the legs. In a micro-g environment, with the loss of a [[Hydrostatic pressure|hydrostatic gradient]], some fluid quickly redistributes toward the chest and upper body; sensed as 'overload' of circulating blood volume.<ref name=":42">{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/23924131_Current_status_and_future_direction_of_NASA's_Space_Life_Sciences_Program|title=Current status and future direction of NASA's Space Life Sciences Program (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-11-27}}</ref> In the micro-g environment, the newly sensed excess blood volume is adjusted by expelling excess fluid into tissues and cells (12-15% volume reduction) and [[red blood cell]]s are adjusted downward to maintain a normal concentration (relative [[anemia]]).<ref name=":42" /> In the absence of gravity, venous blood will rush to the [[Atrium (heart)|right atrium]] because the force of gravity is no longer pulling the blood down into the vessels of the legs and abdomen, resulting in increased [[stroke volume]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esa.int/esapub/bulletin/bulletin119/bul119_chap4.pdf|title=What Happens to the Human Heart in Space - Parabolic Flights Provide Some Answers|last=Aubert|first=Andre|date=August 2004|website=ESA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 25, 2017}}</ref> These fluid shifts become more dangerous upon returning to a regular gravity environment as the body will attempt to adapt to the reintroduction of gravity. The reintroduction of gravity again will pull the fluid downward, but now there would be a deficit in both circulating fluid and red blood cells. The decrease in cardiac filling pressure and stroke volume during the orthostatic stress due to a decreased blood volume is what causes [[orthostatic intolerance]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wieling|first=Wouter|last2=Halliwill|first2=John R|last3=Karemaker|first3=John M|date=2002-01-01|title=Orthostatic intolerance after space flight|journal=The Journal of Physiology|volume=538|issue=Pt 1|pages=1|doi=10.1113/jphysiol.2001.013372|issn=0022-3751|pmc=2290012|pmid=11773310}}</ref> Orthostatic intolerance can result in temporary loss of consciousness and posture, due to the lack of pressure and stroke volume.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stewart|first=Julian M.|date=2013-05-01|title=Common Syndromes of Orthostatic Intolerance|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/131/5/968|journal=Pediatrics|language=en|volume=131|issue=5|pages=968–980|doi=10.1542/peds.2012-2610|issn=0031-4005|pmid=23569093|pmc=3639459}}</ref> More chronic orthostatic intolerance can result in additional symptoms such as [[nausea]], [[Sleep disorder|sleep problems]], and other vasomotor symptoms as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stewart|first=Julian M.|title=Chronic orthostatic intolerance and the postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S002234760400650X|journal=The Journal of Pediatrics|volume=145|issue=6|pages=725–730|doi=10.1016/j.jpeds.2004.06.084|year=2004|pmc=4511479}}</ref>
Many studies on the physiological effects of weightlessness on the cardiovascular system are done in parabolic flights. It is one of the only feasible options to combine with human experiments, making parabolic flights the only way to investigate the true effects of the micro-g environment on a body without traveling into space.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/953694996|title=Cardiovascular system, red blood cells, and oxygen transport in microgravity|others=Gunga, Hanns-Christian,, Ahlefeld, Victoria Weller von,, Coriolano, Hans-Joachim Appell,, Werner, Andreas,, Hoffmann, Uwe,|isbn=9783319332260|location=Switzerland|oclc=953694996}}</ref> Parabolic flight studies have provided a broad range of results regarding changes in the cardiovascular system in a micro-g environment. Parabolic flight studies have increased the understanding of orthostatic intolerance and decreased peripheral blood flow suffered by Astronauts returning to Earth. Due to the loss of blood to pump, the heart can atrophy in a micro-g environment. A weakened heart can result in low blood volume, low blood pressure and affect the body's ability to send oxygen to the brain without the individual becoming dizzy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/652.html|title=Cardiac Atrophy and Diastolic Dysfunction During and After Long Duration Spaceflight: Functional Consequences for Orthostatic Intolerance, Exercise Capability and Risk for Cardiac Arrhythmias (Integrated Cardiovascular)|last=Bungo|first=Michael|date=March 23, 2016|website=NASA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 25, 2017}}</ref> [[Heart arrhythmia|Heart rhythm disturbances]] have also been seen among astronauts, but it is not clear whether this was due to pre-existing conditions of effects of a micro-g environment.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Fritsch-Yelle|first=Janice M.|last2=Leuenberger|first2=Urs A.|last3=D’Aunno|first3=Dominick S.|last4=Rossum|first4=Alfred C.|last5=Brown|first5=Troy E.|last6=Wood|first6=Margie L.|last7=Josephson|first7=Mark E.|last8=Goldberger|first8=Ary L.|title=An Episode of Ventricular Tachycardia During Long-Duration Spaceflight|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0002-9149(98)00179-9|journal=The American Journal of Cardiology|volume=81|issue=11|pages=1391–1392|doi=10.1016/s0002-9149(98)00179-9|year=1998}}</ref> One current countermeasure includes drinking a salt solution, which increases the viscosity of blood and would subsequently increase blood pressure which would mitigate post micro-g environment orthostatic intolerance. Another countermeasure includes administration of [[midodrine]], which is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic agonist. Midodrine produces arterial and venous constriction resulting in an increase in blood pressure by baroreceptor reflexes.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/768427940|title=Fundamentals of space medicine|last=1956-|first=Clément, Gilles,|date=2011|publisher=Published jointly by Microcosm Press|isbn=9781441999054|edition=2nd|location=El Segundo, Calif.|oclc=768427940}}</ref>
== Impacts to worker safety == Space Motion Sickness can lead to degraded astronaut performance.<ref name=":03" /> SMS threatens operational requirements, reduces situational awareness, and threatens the safety of those exposed to micro-g environments.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1006502642|title=The human body and weightlessness : operational effects, problems and countermeasures|last=William,|first=Thornton,|others=Bonato, Frederick,|isbn=9783319328294|location=Cham, Switzerland|oclc=1006502642}}</ref> Lost muscle mass leads to difficulty with movement, especially when astronauts return to earth. This can pose a safety issue if the need for emergency egress were to arise. Loss of muscle power makes it extremely difficult, if not impossible, for astronauts to climb through emergency egress hatches or create unconventional exit spaces in the case of a crash upon landing. Additionally, bone resorption and inadequate hydration in space can lead to the formation of kidney stones, and subsequent sudden incapacitation due to pain.<ref name=":33" /> If this were to occur during critical phases of flight, a capsule crash leading to worker injury and/or death could result. Short-term and long-term health effects have been seen in the cardiovascular system from exposure to the micro-g environment that would limit those exposed after they return to Earth or a regular gravity environment. Steps need to be taken to ensure proper precautions are taken into consideration when dealing a micro-g environment for worker safety.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Orthostatic intolerance can lead to temporary loss of consciousness due to the lack of pressure and stroke volume. This loss of consciousness inhibits and endangers those affected and can lead to deadly consequences.<ref name=":2" />

[[File:Inconsolable grief.jpg|thumb|250px|Inconsolable grief by [[Ivan Kramskoi]]]]
'''Miscarriage and grief''' are both an event and subsequent process of grieving that develops in response to a [[miscarriage]].<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/> Almost all those experiencing a miscarriage experience [[grief]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.postpartumprogress.com/13-things-you-should-know-about-grief-after-miscarriage-or-baby-loss|title=13 Things To Know About Grief After Miscarriage or Loss|date=2013-05-16|work=Postpartum Progress|access-date=2017-09-09|language=English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909192535/http://www.postpartumprogress.com/13-things-you-should-know-about-grief-after-miscarriage-or-baby-loss|archivedate=September 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=:2>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miscarriagesupport.org.nz/grief-issues-special-to-miscarriage/|title=Grief Issues Special to Miscarriage – the broken bond|website=www.miscarriagesupport.org.nz|language=English|access-date=2017-09-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170704235250/http://www.miscarriagesupport.org.nz/grief-issues-special-to-miscarriage/|archivedate=July 4, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> This event is often considered to be identical to the loss of a child and has been described as traumatic.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hospicefoundation.org/Grief-(1)|title=Hospice Foundation Of America - Grief|website=hospicefoundation.org|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref><ref name="lok">Lok, I. H., & Neugebauer, R. (2007). Psychological morbidity following miscarriage. Best Practice & Research Clinical Obstetrics & Gynaecology, 21(2), 229-247.</ref><ref name="buon">{{Cite journal|last=Bellieni|first=Carlo V.|last2=Buonocore|first2=Giuseppe|date=2013-07-01|title=Abortion and subsequent mental health: Review of the literature|journal=Psychiatry and Clinical Neurosciences|language=en|volume=67|issue=5|pages=301–310|doi=10.1111/pcn.12067|pmid=23859662|issn=1440-1819}}</ref> "Devastation" is another descriptor of miscarriage.<ref name="Nelson 380–392">{{Cite journal|last=Nelson|first=S. Katherine|last2=Robbins|first2=Megan L.|last3=Andrews|first3=Sara E.|last4=Sweeny|first4=Kate|date=2017-03-01|title=Disrupted Transition to Parenthood: Gender Moderates the Association Between Miscarriage and Uncertainty About Conception|journal=Sex Roles|language=en|volume=76|issue=5–6|pages=380–392|doi=10.1007/s11199-015-0564-z|issn=0360-0025}}</ref> Grief differs from the emotion [[sadness]].<ref>[http://www.thesaurus.com/browse/grief][https://www.powerthesaurus.org/grief/synonyms][https://books.google.ca/books?id=dF2WpFK3A5gC&pg=PA372 Some thesauruses consider 'sadness' to be a synonym for grief. See]</ref> Sadness is an emotion along with grief, on the other hand, is a response to the loss a of the bond or [[affection]] was formed and is a process rather than one single emotional response. Grief is not equivalent to depression.<ref name = beutel/> Grief also has physical, [[Cognition|cognitive]], behavioral, social, cultural, and philosophical dimensions.<ref name="auto1" /> Bereavement and [[mourning]] refer to the ongoing state of loss, and grief is the reaction to that loss.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/><ref name = loyd/><ref name = Robinson2014provision>{{Cite journal | title = Provision of information support to women who have suffered an early miscarriage (review) | first = Joanne | last = Robinson | journal = British Journal of Midwifery | date = March 2014 | volume = 22 | number = 3 | pages = 175–180}}</ref> Emotional responses may be [[Bitter (emotion)|bitterness]], [[anxiety]], [[anger]], [[Surprise (emotion)|surprise]], [[fear]], and [[disgust]] and [[blame|blaming]] others; these responses may persist for months.<ref name = sing/><ref name = aafp/><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Hunter|first=Amanda|last2=Tussis|first2=Lorena|last3=MacBeth|first3=Angus|date=2017-12-01|title=The presence of anxiety, depression and stress in women and their partners during pregnancies following perinatal loss: A meta-analysis|journal=Journal of Affective Disorders|volume=223|pages=153–164|doi=10.1016/j.jad.2017.07.004|issn=1573-2517|pmid=28755623}}</ref><ref name="Robinson2011dil" /><ref>Daniel Goleman, ''Emotional Intelligence'' (London 1996) p. 271</ref> Self-esteem can be diminished as another response to miscarriage.<ref name = sing/> Not only does miscarriage tend to be a traumatic event, women describe their treatment afterwards to be worse than the miscarriage itself.<ref name = jeve>{{Cite journal|last=Jeve|first=YadavaB|last2=Davies|first2=William|date=2014-07-01|title=Evidence-based management of recurrent miscarriages|url=http://www.jhrsonline.org/text.asp?2014/7/3/159/142475|journal=Journal of Human Reproductive Sciences|language=en|volume=7|issue=3|pages=159–69|doi=10.4103/0974-1208.142475|pmid=25395740|pmc=4229790}}</ref>
A miscarriage can often be "heart-breaking".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Garrido-Gimenez|first=Carmen|last2=Alijotas-Reig|first2=Jaume|date=2015-03-01|title=Recurrent miscarriage: causes, evaluation and management|url=http://pmj.bmj.com/content/91/1073/151|journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal|language=en|volume=91|issue=1073|pages=151–162|doi=10.1136/postgradmedj-2014-132672|issn=0032-5473|pmid=25681385|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910181311/http://pmj.bmj.com/content/91/1073/151|archivedate=September 10, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A miscarriage can effect the women, [[husband]], partner, [[sibling]]s, [[grandparent]]s, the whole [[family]] system and friends.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Martin P.|last2=Baker|first2=Sarah R.|date=June 2004|title=Implications of coping repertoire as predictors of men's stress, anxiety and depression following pregnancy, childbirth and miscarriage: a longitudinal study|journal=Journal of Psychosomatic Obstetrics and Gynaecology|volume=25|issue=2|pages=87–98|issn=0167-482X|pmid=15715032}}</ref> Almost all those experiencing a miscarriage go through a [[grief|grieving]] process.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss>{{cite journal|last1=Robinson|first1=GE|title=Pregnancy loss.|journal=Best Practice & Research. Clinical Obstetrics & Gynaecology|date=January 2014|volume=28|issue=1|pages=169–78|pmid=24047642|doi=10.1016/j.bpobgyn.2013.08.012}}</ref><ref name=":1"/><ref name=":2"/><ref name="sing" /> Serious emotional impact is usually experienced immediately after the miscarriage.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/> Some may go through the same loss when an [[ectopic pregnancy]] is terminated.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Miscarriage/Pages/Causes.aspx|title=Miscarriage - Causes - NHS Choices|first=NHS|last=Choices|website=www.nhs.uk|date=2017-12-07}}</ref><ref name="webmd">{{cite web | last = Rosenthal | first = M. Sara | title = The Second Trimester | work = The Gynecological Sourcebook | publisher = WebMD | year = 1999 | url = http://www.webmd.com/content/article/4/1680_51802.htm | accessdate = December 18, 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061201085538/http://www.webmd.com/content/article/4/1680_51802.htm | archivedate = December 1, 2006 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> In some, the realization of the loss can take weeks. Providing [[family support]] to those experiencing the loss can be challenging because some find comfort in [[Psychotherapy|talking]] about the miscarriage while others may find the event painful to discuss. The father of the baby can have the same sense of loss. Expressing feelings of grief and loss can sometimes be harder for men. Some women are able to begin planning their next pregnancy after a few weeks of having the miscarriage. For others, planning another pregnancy can be difficult.<ref name=uk>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Miscarriage/Pages/Complications.aspx|title=Miscarriage - Afterwards - NHS Choices|last=Choices|first=NHS|website=www.nhs.uk|accessdate=September 5, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905055121/http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Miscarriage/Pages/Complications.aspx|archivedate=September 5, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=misorg>{{cite web | url = https://www.miscarriageassociation.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Thinking-about-another-pregnancy.pdf | title = Thinking About Another Pregnancy | publisher = Miscarriage Association | accessdate = 4 September 2017 | date = 2013 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170905051002/https://www.miscarriageassociation.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Thinking-about-another-pregnancy.pdf | archivedate = September 5, 2017 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Organizations exist that provide information and counselling to help those who have had a miscarriage.<ref name=uk/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meredith|first=Pamela|last2=Wilson|first2=Trish|last3=Branjerdporn|first3=Grace|last4=Strong|first4=Jenny|last5=Desha|first5=Laura|date=2017-01-05|title="Not just a normal mum": a qualitative investigation of a support service for women who are pregnant subsequent to perinatal loss|journal=BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth|volume=17|issue=1|pages=6|doi=10.1186/s12884-016-1200-9|pmid=28056861|pmc=5217635|issn=1471-2393}}</ref><ref name = whealth>{{Cite web|url=https://www.womenshealth.gov/pregnancy/youre-pregnant-now-what/pregnancy-loss|title=Pregnancy loss |website=womenshealth.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-09-18|date=2016-12-14 }}{{PD-notice}}</ref> Some women have a higher risk of developing prolonged grief and complicated grief than others.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kulathilaka|first=Susil|last2=Hanwella|first2=Raveen|last3=de Silva|first3=Varuni A.|date=2016-04-12|title=Depressive disorder and grief following spontaneous abortion|journal=BMC Psychiatry|volume=16|pages=100|doi=10.1186/s12888-016-0812-y|issn=1471-244X|pmc=4830021|pmid=27071969}}</ref>
==Psychological impact== {{See also|Miscarriage and mental illness}} Miscarriage has an emotional effect and can also lead to psychological disorders. One discorder that can develop is primary maternal preoccupation. This is defined as a " ...'special psychiatric condition' in which the pregnant woman identifies with her baby, highlights the crisis a woman faces when the baby with whom she is preoccupied and identified dies..."<ref name="loyd" /> Grieving manifests itself differently for each woman after miscarriage. It may often go unrecognized.<ref name="loyd"/> The grief that follows a miscarriage resembles, but is not the same as, the grief experienced after the loss of a family member.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brier|first=Norman|date=2008-03-17|title=Grief Following Miscarriage: A Comprehensive Review of the Literature|journal=Journal of Women's Health|volume=17|issue=3|pages=451–464|doi=10.1089/jwh.2007.0505|pmid=18345996|issn=1540-9996|citeseerx=10.1.1.473.673}}</ref> Disbelief, [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[anger]], and yearning, are described as being a part of the normal grieving process.<ref name = kirs/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kinsey|first=Cara Bicking|last2=Baptiste-Roberts|first2=Kesha|last3=Zhu|first3=Junjia|last4=Kjerulff|first4=Kristen H.|date=2015-02-01|title=Effect of Previous Miscarriage on Depressive Symptoms During Subsequent Pregnancy and Postpartum in the First Baby Study|journal=Maternal and Child Health Journal|language=en|volume=19|issue=2|pages=391–400|doi=10.1007/s10995-014-1521-0|pmid=24894728|issn=1092-7875|pmc=4256135}}</ref><ref name = beutel>{{Cite journal|last=Beutel|first=M.|last2=Deckardt|first2=R.|last3=von Rad|first3=M.|last4=Weiner|first4=H.|date=November 1995|title=Grief and depression after miscarriage: their separation, antecedents, and course|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|volume=57|issue=6|pages=517–526|issn=0033-3174|pmid=8600477}}</ref> These reactions remain from three to nine months after the loss. Forty-one percent of parents experience a normal, expected decline in grief in the first two years while 59% were delayed in the resolution of their grief.<ref name="kirs" />
Grieving can create feelings of [[loneliness]].<ref name=":0" /> This grieving has been called a type of [[psychological trauma]].<ref name="loyd">{{cite journal|last1=Lloyd Jones|first1=Sarah|year=2015|title=The Psychological Miscarriage: An Exploration of Women's Experience of Miscarriage in the Light of Winnicott's 'Primary Maternal Preoccupation', The Process of Grief According to Bowlby and Parkes, and Klein's Theory of Mourning|journal=British Journal of Psychotherapy|volume=31|issue=4|pages=433–447|doi=10.1111/bjp.12172|issn=0265-9883}}</ref><ref name="lok" /> Other serious consequences can develop including depression, [[anxiety disorder]], [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress disorder]], and [[Somatic symptom disorder|somatoform disorder]]. These responses all are associated with grieving after a miscarriage.<ref name="ce" /> Some women are able to complete the grieving process a few weeks after the miscarriage and start anticipating their next pregnancy. Planning another pregnancy is traumatic for others. The impact of a miscarriage can be "crippling" psychologically.<ref name="sing" /> Anger can be directed toward those who have had successful pregnancies and children.<ref name="lok" /><ref name="auto1" /> A woman can grieve the "loss of a future child" and question her own role as a mother.<ref name="lok" /> They may blame themselves or their partner for the miscarriage.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.webmd.com/baby/grief-after-miscarriage#1|title=Grief After Miscarriage|work=WebMD|access-date=2017-09-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=Robinson2011dil/><ref name=":6"/>
Unsuccessful attempts to become pregnant through [[In vitro fertilisation|in vitro fertilization]] (IVF) can also illicit a similar grief response in women.<ref name="Robinson2011dil">{{cite journal|last1=Robinson|first1=Gail Erlick|title=Dilemmas Related to Pregnancy Loss|journal=The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease|volume=199|issue=8|year=2011|pages=571–574|issn=0022-3018|doi=10.1097/NMD.0b013e318225f31e|pmid=21814082}}</ref> Those experiencing a late miscarriage may have more significant distress compared to those who have experienced a miscarriage in the first trimester.<ref name="ce">{{Cite journal|last=Scheidt|first=CE|date=2007|title=Trauerverarbeitung nach Prä- und Perinatalverlust ( Mourning processing after pre-and perinatal loss)|journal=Psychother Psych Med|volume=57|issue=1|pages=4–11|doi=10.1055/s-2006-951906|pmid=17357028}}</ref> Even depression can occur.<ref name="loyd" />
"Women today...are aught in a unique historical moment: technology encourages them to form emotional attachments to their pregnancies, but society has not developed traditions to cushion the shock when those attachmets are shattered."{{sfn | Seftel | page = 62}}
Descriptions of the miscarriage are expressed in non-clinical terms by those who have experienced the event.
{| class="wikitable" !Descriptors !References ! ! |- |devastating |<ref name="Nelson 380–392"/> | | |- |shocked |<ref name = whealth/> | | |- |pregnancy loss |{{sfn | Softel | page = 57}} | | |- |lack of acknowledgement |{{sfn | Softel | page = 57}} | | |- |stunned |<ref name = whealth/> | | |- |not socially acceptable |{{sfn | Softel | page = 57}} | | |- |guilty |<ref name = whealth/>{{sfn|Seftel|page = 58}} | | |- |shame |{{sfn|Seftel|page = 58}} | | |- |sorrow |{{sfn|Seftel|page = 58}} | | |- |despair |{{sfn|Seftel|page = 58}} | | |- |angry |<ref name = whealth/>{{sfn|Seftel|page = 58}} | | |- |cheated |<ref name = whealth/> | | |- |numbness |{{sfn | Softel | page = 57}} | | |- |drowning |{{sfn | Softel | page = 57}} | | |- |envy |{{sfn|Seftel|page = 58}} | | |- |}
===Trauma=== Miscarriage has been found to be a traumatic event and a major loss for women.<ref name = jeve/> Pregnancy loss, including induced abortion is a risk factor for mental illness. The impact of miscarriage can be underestimated.{{sfn|Chritiansen| page=87}}<ref name=buon/> The trauma can be compounded if the miscarriage was accompanied by visible and relatively large amounts of blood loss.{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} The trauma of miscarriage can be compounded if the miscarriage was accompanied by visible and relatively large amounts of blood loss.{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} <!--==Risks==--> Bipolar disorders are associated with miscarriage. Depression and bilpolar disorder becomes evident after a miscarriage in 43% of women. Some women are more likely to experience complicated and prolonged grief than others.<ref name = kirs/>
==== Mental health ==== Women experiencing miscarriage are at risk for grief reactions, anxiety or depression.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/> Obsessiveness regarding the miscarriage can develop.{{Medical citation needed|date=September 2017}}{{sfn|Seftel|page = 60}} Primary maternal preoccupation is also considered a consequence of miscarriage. This condition can occur if a woman who develop a close bond "with her baby" experiences the loss of the pregnancy.<ref name="loyd" />{{Medical citation needed|date=September 2017}}
===Complicated grief=== Different grieving "styles" can exist and vary between individuals. There can be a complete avoidance of dealing with the memories of the miscarriage and there can be an "obsessive" concentration on an event in the miscarriage. This is in contrast with the expected ability to "reminisce about the loss of a loved one".{{sfn|Seftel|page = 60}} [[Prolonged grief disorder|Complicated grief]] differs from the more common form of grief that occurs after a miscarriage. The grieving process associated with other events such as the loss of a spouse or parent is expected to decline in predictable and steady rate. This not true for those experiencing grief after a miscarriage because only 41% follow the expected decline in grief while most, 59% do not fit this pattern.<ref name = kirs>{{Cite journal|last=Kersting|first=Anette|last2=Wagner|first2=Birgit|date=June 2012|title=Complicated grief after perinatal loss|journal=Dialogues in Clinical Neuroscience|volume=14|issue=2|pages=187–194|issn=1294-8322|pmc=3384447|pmid=22754291}}</ref>
===Stress and posttraumatic stress disorder=== Miscarriage is associated with post traumatic stress disorder.<ref name="buon"/><ref name=daug>{{Cite journal|last=Daugirdaitė|first=Viltė|last2=Akker|first2=Olga van den|last3=Purewal|first3=Satvinder|date=2015|title=Posttraumatic Stress and Posttraumatic Stress Disorder after Termination of Pregnancy and Reproductive Loss: A Systematic Review|url=https://www.hindawi.com/journals/jp/2015/646345/|journal=Journal of Pregnancy|language=en|volume=2015|pages=1–14|doi=10.1155/2015/646345|pmid=25734016|pmc=4334933|issn=2090-2727}}</ref><ref name = kirs/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bowles|first=Stephen V.|last2=James|first2=Larry C.|last3=Solursh|first3=Diane S.|last4=Yancey|first4=Michael K.|last5=Epperly|first5=Ted D.|last6=Folen|first6=Raymond A.|last7=Masone|first7=Maryann|date=2000-03-15|title=Acute and Post-traumatic Stress Disorder After Spontaneous Abortion|url=http://www.aafp.org/afp/2000/0315/p1689.html|journal=American Family Physician|language=en|volume=61|issue=6|issn=0002-838X}}</ref> Risks for developing PTSD after miscarriage are: emotional pain, expressions of emotion, and low levels of social support.<ref name= daug/> Even if relatively low levels of stress occur after the miscarriage, symptoms of PTSD including flashbacks, intrusive thoughts, dissociation and hyperarousal can later develop.{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} The effects of stress can complicate miscarriage.<ref name = jeve/><ref name=":5" /> Miscarriage is a stressful event and because stress is a risk factor for subsequent miscarriage, its presence can become part of cycle that continues.<ref name="jeve" /> Lower stress levels are associated with more favorable outcomes in future pregnancies while higher stress levels increase the risk.{{sfn|Christiansen|page = 92}}
==Recovery== Physical recovery from miscarriage can have an effect on emotional disturbances. The body has to recover from the sudden pregnancy loss. In some instances f[[Fatigue (medical)|fatigue]] is present. [[Insomnia]] can be a problem.<ref name="sing" /><ref name="aafp" /><ref name="auto1"/> The miscarriage is very upsetting to the family and can generate very strong emotions. Some women may feel that the miscarriage occurred because they somehow had caused it. Others may blame the father or partner for the miscarriage.<ref name="sing" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Hale|first=B.|date=2007-01-01|title=Culpability and blame after pregnancy loss|url=http://jme.bmj.com/content/33/1/24|journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|language=en|volume=33|issue=1|pages=24–27|doi=10.1136/jme.2005.015560|issn=0306-6800|pmid=17209106|pmc=2598085}}</ref> Coping with a miscarriage can very greatly between women and families.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/><ref name = aafp/> Some find it difficult to talk about the miscarriage.<ref name = aafp>{{Cite journal|date=2007-11-01|title=Pregnancy Loss: What You Should Know|journal=American Family Physician|volume = 76|issue=9|pages=1347–8|url=http://www.aafp.org/afp/2007/1101/p1347.html|language=en|pmid=18019879|author1=American Academy of Family Physicians}}</ref><ref name="sing" /> The narratives of women tend to coincide with quantified and measurable effects.<ref name = loyd/> Some women engage in activities that are believed to aid in recovery such as therapy, [[religion]] and art.{{sfn|Seftel|page = 57}} <!--Interventions==-->Counseling can be offered but effective interventions to assist in recovery have been difficult to identify due to the reports of efficacy<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Neugebauer|first=Richard|last2=Kline|first2=Jennie|last3=Bleiberg|first3=Kathryn|last4=Baxi|first4=Laxmi|last5=Markowitz|first5=John C.|last6=Rosing|first6=Mark|last7=Levin|first7=Bruce|last8=Keith|first8=Jessica|date=2007|title=Preliminary open trial of interpersonal counseling for subsyndromal depression following miscarriage|journal=Depression and Anxiety|volume=24|issue=3|pages=219–222|doi=10.1002/da.20150|issn=1091-4269|pmid=16988939}}{{PD-notice}}</ref> and ineffective counseling. Comparisons are hard to make.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/><ref name="sing" /><ref name="ce" /> Despite the lack of studies that describe effective interventions for those with grief after a miscarriage, some clinicians still offer counselling and follow-up to help women recover and adapt to the loss.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Evans|first=Rachel|date=Jun 20–26, 2012|title=Emotional care for women who experience miscarriage|journal=Nursing Standard (Royal College of Nursing (Great Britain): 1987)|volume=26|issue=42|pages=35–41|doi=10.7748/ns2012.06.26.42.35.c9160|issn=0029-6570|pmid=22908762}}</ref>
Recommendations to help recover from the event include: * Turning to loved ones and friends for support. Sharing feelings and asking for help when needed. * Talking to the partner about the miscarriage. * Keeping in mind that men and women cope with loss in different ways.<ref name="whealth" /><ref name=":3" /> * Making good choices for health and well-being such as: eating healthy foods, keeping active, and getting enough sleep to help restore energy. * Joining a support group. A support group might help with feelings of being alone in the loss.<ref name="whealth" /><ref name=":3" /> * Doing something in remembrance of the baby. * Seeking help from a grief counselor, especially if the grief doesn't ease with time.<ref name = whealth/>
Generally, the impact of experiencing miscarriage is underestimated.<ref name="buon"/>{{sfn|Chritiansen| page=87}} Other methods used to promote recovery are be relaxation techniques, guided imagery, and "thought-stopping". Even Gestalt role-playing has been used. Some women can "emotionally relocate the child", redefine a relationship "with the missing child", and engage in "continuing the bond" to incorporate the loss into their life experiences.{{sfn | Seftel | page = 60}}
Women who have miscarried report that they were dissatisfied with the care they received from physicians and nurses.<ref name=Robinson2014provision/> One observer highlights the insensitivity of some health care providers when they approach the grieving mother "...by playing down her emotion as somehow an irrational response..."<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Christiansen|first=Dorte M.|title=Posttraumatic stress disorder in parents following infant death: A systematic review|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0272735816300903|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|language=en|volume=51|pages=60–74|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2016.10.007|pmid=27838460|year=2017}}</ref><ref name=":4" /> Clinicians may not recognize the psychological impact of the miscarriage and can "expect parents to move on with their lives."<ref name=":6" />
Since the experiences of women can vary so widely, sensitive nursing care afterward is appropriate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Radford|first=Eleanor J|last2=Hughes|first2=Mark|date=2015-06-01|title=Women's experiences of early miscarriage: implications for nursing care|journal=Journal of Clinical Nursing|volume=24|issue=11–12|pages=1457–1465|doi=10.1111/jocn.12781|pmid=25662397|issn=1365-2702}}</ref>
==Children and concerns about future pregnancies== One emotional response to miscarriage is the strong apprehension that can develop anticipating a subsequent pregnancy.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/><ref name = sing>{{cite journal | publisher = Singapore Nursing Journal | title = The impact miscarriage on women's psychological well being and interventions: A literature review | first = Marianne | last = Wen-Yi | first2 = Lam | last2 = Ka Shun | first3 = Priscilla Jia | last3 = Ling Ho et.al }}</ref><ref name = aafp/> Procreation abilities may also be questioned by the woman.<ref name = sing/><ref name="lok" /> Significant distress can develop in the other children in the family when they think a sibling has died. They may regard this as a baby they did not get to meet. They can also experience grief and guilt find it difficult to express these emotions to their parents. The siblings may feel a need to act as if everything is the same and that they are unaffected in an attempt to protect their parents from their own feelings. Children can also need help, understanding and the ability to make sense of the event.<ref>{{cite book|title=Becoming Parents and Overcoming Obstacles : Understanding the Experience of Miscarriage, Premature Births, Infertility, and Postnatal Depression|last=Quagliata|first=Emanuela|publisher=Karnac Books|year=2013|isbn=9781782200185|location=City|pages=64}}</ref>
==Memorials and burial== [[Ritual]]s that recognize the loss can be important in coping.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women's reproductive mental health across the lifespan|others=Lynn-Barnes, Diana|isbn=9783319051154|location=Cham|oclc=880941778}}</ref> Family and friends often conduct a memorial or burial service.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/><ref name=uk/> Hospitals also can provide support and help memorialize the event. Depending on locale others desire to have a private ceremony.<ref name=uk/> The religious faith of the woman and family impacts the grief process.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cowchock|first=F. S.|last2=Ellestad|first2=S. E.|last3=Meador|first3=K. G.|last4=Koenig|first4=H. G.|last5=Hooten|first5=E. G.|last6=Swamy|first6=G. K.|date=December 2011|title=Religiosity is an important part of coping with grief in pregnancy after a traumatic second trimester loss|journal=Journal of Religion and Health|volume=50|issue=4|pages=901–910|doi=10.1007/s10943-011-9528-y|issn=1573-6571|pmid=21861239}}</ref> Conversely, the lack of recognition that the miscarriage has occurred by family and friends can be troubling and add to the trauma of the event.<ref name=Keefe-Cooperman/> <!--==Narratives== Women discuss their miscarriage and interact with others who have had the same experience. This is one way that their loss is recognized, publically mourned and socially accepted.{{sfn | Seftel | page = 57}}-->
==In culture== Grieving after the loss of a child through miscarriage in other cultures can vary from western culture.<ref name="Klass2015">{{cite journal|last1=Klass|first1=Dennis|title=Book Reviews of Narratives of Sorrow and Dignity: Japanese Women, Pregnancy Loss, and Modern Rituals of Grieving|journal=OMEGA - Journal of Death and Dying|volume=70|issue=4|year=2015|pages=454–457|issn=0030-2228|doi=10.1177/0030222815573931}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://hospicefoundation.org/Grief-(1)/What-to-Expect | title=Hospice Foundation of America - What is Grief?}}</ref> An individual’s [[culture]] plays a large role in determining an inappropriate pattern of grief, and it is appropriate to take into account cultural norms before reaching a complicated grief diagnosis.<ref name="one">{{cite journal|last1=Shear|first1=MK|last2=Simon|first2=N|last3=Wall|first3=M|last4=Zisook|first4=S|last5=Neimeyer|first5=R|last6=Duan|first6=N|last7=Reynolds|first7=C|last8=Lebowitz|first8=B|last9=Sung|first9=S|last10=Ghesquiere|first10=A|last11=Gorscak|first11=B|last12=Clayton|first12=P|last13=Ito|first13=M|last14=Nakajima|first14=S|last15=Konishi|first15=T|last16=Melhem|first16=N|last17=Meert|first17=K|last18=Schiff|first18=M|last19=O'Connor|first19=MF|last20=First|first20=M|last21=Sareen|first21=J|last22=Bolton|first22=J|last23=Skritskaya|first23=N|last24=Mancini|first24=AD|last25=Keshaviah|first25=A|title=Complicated grief and related bereavement issues for DSM-5.|journal=Depression and Anxiety|date=February 2011|volume=28|issue=2|pages=103–17|doi=10.1002/da.20780|pmid=21284063|pmc=3075805}}</ref> There are cultural differences in emotional levels, how these are expressed and how long they are expressed. External symptoms of grief differ in non-Western cultures, presenting increased [[somatization]].<ref name="seventythree">Horwitz, A. V., & Wakefield, J. C. (2007). The Loss of Sadness: How Psychiatry Transformed Normal Sorrow Into Depressive Disorder. Oxford University Press.</ref> Narratives by Swedish women include their own perception of losing a child. Investigations describe their grief over their miscarriage: "When miscarriage occurs it is not a gore, an embryo, or a fetus they lose, it is their child. They feel that they are the cause of the miscarriage through something they have done, eaten, or thought. They feel [[Abandonment (emotional)|abandonment]] and they grieve for their profound loss; they are actually in bereavement."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Adolfsson|first=Annsofie|last2=Larsson|first2=P. G.|last3=Wijma|first3=Barbro|last4=Berterö|first4=Carina|date=June 2004|title=Guilt and emptiness: women's experiences of miscarriage|journal=Health Care for Women International|volume=25|issue=6|pages=543–560|doi=10.1080/07399330490444821|issn=0739-9332|pmid=15354621}}</ref> Native American women have cut their long hair following the death of a family member.{{sfn |Seftel | page = 59}} The narratives of women tend to coincide with quantified and measurable effects.<ref name = loyd/> In women who are induced to have an abortion, an identical grieving process can occur.<ref name=Keefe-Cooperman>{{Cite journal|last=Keefe-Cooperman|first=Kathleen|date=2005-06-01|title=A Comparison of Grief as Related to Miscarriage and Termination for Fetal Abnormality|journal=OMEGA - Journal of Death and Dying|language=en|volume=50|issue=4|pages=281–300|doi=10.2190/QFDW-LGEY-CYLM-N4LW|issn=0030-2228}}</ref> The emotional responses to a spontaneous abortion (miscarriage) and an elective abortion are sometimes identical.<ref name=Robinson2014pregloss/> Spanish women experience grief in much the same way in the rest of Western culture.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ridaura|first=Isabel|last2=Penelo|first2=Eva|last3=Raich|first3=Rosa M.|date=February 2017|title=Depressive symptomatology and grief in Spanish women who have suffered a perinatal loss|journal=Psicothema|volume=29|issue=1|pages=43–48|doi=10.7334/psicothema2016.151|issn=1886-144X|pmid=28126057}}</ref> Some women find online forums helpful.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Sawicka|first=Maja|date=2017-05-01|title=Searching for a Narrative of Loss: Interactional Ordering of Ambiguous Grief|journal=Symbolic Interaction|language=en|volume=40|issue=2|pages=229–246|doi=10.1002/symb.270|issn=1533-8665}}</ref>
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Depression (mood)]] * [[Sorrow (emotion)]] * [[Joie de vivre]] * [[Melancholia]] * [[Mood (psychology)]] * [[Infant mortality]] * [[Miscarriage & Infant Loss Memorial Book]] {{div col end}}

Mental illness can be a consequence of [[miscarriage]] or early pregnancy loss.<ref name="BMJ Best Practice">{{Cite web|url=http://us.bestpractice.bmj.com/best-practice/monograph/666.html|title=Miscarriage|last=BMJ Best Practice|first=|date=|website=us.bestpractice.bmj.com|language=en|others=Ida Muslim, Jothi Doraiswamy, Acknowledgements|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-08}}</ref><ref name = rand>{{Cite journal | last1 =Randolph |first1 = Amber L. | last2 = Hruby | first2 = Brittaney T.| first3 =Shaakira | last3=Sharif | title = Counseling Women Who Have Experienced Pregnancy Loss: A Review of the Literature | date = 4 April 2015 | number = 1 | volume = 14| publisher = Adult Span Journal}}</ref> Even though women can develop long-term psychiatric symptoms after a miscarriage, acknowledging the potential of mental illness is not usually considered.<ref name=Christiansen2017/> A [[Mental disorder|mental illness]] can develop in women who have experienced one or more [[miscarriage]]s after the event or even years later.{{sfn|Seftel|page = }}<ref name="BMJ Best Practice"/> Some data suggest that men and women can be affected up to 15 years after the loss.<ref name="daug" /> Though recognized as a public health problem, studies investigating the mental health status of women following miscarriage are still lacking.<ref name= daug/> [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) can develop in women who have experienced a miscarriage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.figo.org/news/what-psychological-impact-miscarriage-0015410|title=What is the psychological impact of miscarriage? {{!}} FIGO|last=International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics|first=|date=|website=|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-23}}</ref><ref name=daug>{{Cite journal|last=Daugirdaitė|first=Viltė|last2=Akker|first2=Olga van den|last3=Purewal|first3=Satvinder|date=2015|title=Posttraumatic Stress and Posttraumatic Stress Disorder after Termination of Pregnancy and Reproductive Loss: A Systematic Review|url=https://www.hindawi.com/journals/jp/2015/646345/|journal=Journal of Pregnancy|language=en|volume=2015|pages=1–14|doi=10.1155/2015/646345|pmid=25734016|pmc=4334933|issn=2090-2727}}</ref><ref name = kirs/> Risks for developing PTSD after miscarriage include [[Psychological pain|emotional pain]], expressions of emotion, and low levels of [[social support]].<ref name= daug/> Even if relatively low levels of [[Stress (biology)|stress]] occur after the miscarriage, symptoms of PTSD including [[Flashback (psychology)|flashbacks]], [[intrusive thought]]s, [[Dissociation (psychology)|dissociation]] and [[Fight-or-flight response|hyperarousal]] can later develop.{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} [[Clinical depression]] also is associated with miscarriage.<ref name = sche/> Past responses by clinicians have been to prescribe sedatives.<ref>{{cite book | last = Quagliata | first = Emanuela | title = Becoming Parents and Overcoming Obstacles : Understanding the Experience of Miscarriage, Premature Births, Infertility, and Postnatal Depression | publisher = Karnac Books | location = City | year = 2013 | isbn = 9781782200185 }}</ref>
Recurring miscarriage may increase the incidence of intrusive thoughts in women and their partners.<ref name="daug" />
Miscarriage has an emotional effect and can also lead to [[psychological disorders]]. One disorder that can develop is primary maternal preoccupation. This [[psychological trauma]] can develop as a response to early pregnancy loss. [[Anxiety]] can also develop as a result of a miscarriage.<ref name=sche>{{Cite journal|last=Scheidt|first=CE|date=2007|title=Trauerverarbeitung nach Prä- und Perinatalverlust (Mourning processing after pre-and perinatal loss)|journal=Psychother Psych Med|volume=57|issue=1|pages=4–11|doi=10.1055/s-2006-951906|pmid=17357028}}</ref> Women describe the medical treatment that they receive contributed their distress.<ref name= daug/> Even if relatively low levels of [[Stress (biology)|stress]] occur after the miscarriage, symptoms of PTSD including [[Flashback (psychology)|flashbacks]], [[Dissociation (psychology)|dissociation]] and [[Fight-or-flight response|hyperarousal]] can later develop.{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} [[Clinical depression]] also is associated with miscarriage.<ref name = sche/>
Intrusive thoughts can develop after the loss.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} Panic disorder and obsessive thoughts may also develop as a response to a miscarriage.<ref name=":0" /> Men may experience pain and psychological effects but react by adopting “compensatory behaviours” such as increasing consumption of alcohol. Because men can consider their role to be supportive, they may not have their loss recognized.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Due|first=Clemence|last2=Chiarolli|first2=Stephanie|last3=Riggs|first3=Damien W.|date=2017-11-15|title=The impact of pregnancy loss on men's health and wellbeing: a systematic review|journal=BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth|volume=17|issue=1|pages=380|doi=10.1186/s12884-017-1560-9|pmid=29141591|pmc=5688642|issn=1471-2393}}</ref>
==Posttraumatic stress disorder== Women who have had clinical depression before the miscarriage are more likely to develop PTSD.<ref name=Christiansen2017/> [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]] is associated with miscarriage along with other traumatic events associated with pregnancy.<ref name=Christiansen2017>{{cite journal|last1=Christiansen|first1=DM|title=Posttraumatic stress disorder in parents following infant death: A systematic review|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|date=February 2017|volume=51|pages=60–74|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2016.10.007|pmid=27838460}}</ref>{{sfn|Martin|page = 26 }}<ref name = kirs>{{Cite journal|last=Kersting|first=Anette|last2=Wagner|first2=Birgit|date=June 2012|title=Complicated grief after perinatal loss|url=|journal=Dialogues in Clinical Neuroscience|volume=14|issue=2|pages=187–194|pmc=3384447|pmid=22754291}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Daugirdaitė|first1=V|last2=van den Akker|first2=O|last3=Purewal|first3=S|title=Posttraumatic stress and posttraumatic stress disorder after termination of pregnancy and reproductive loss: a systematic review|journal=Journal of Pregnancy|date=2015|volume=2015|pages=1-14|doi=10.1155/2015/646345|pmid=25734016|pmc=4334933}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Those who experience recurrent miscarriage (>3) have a greater risk of developing PTSD than those who have experienced miscarriage once.<ref name=Christiansen2017/> An association between the gender of the infant lost through miscarriage exists whereby there is an increased chance of developing PTSD if the infant was a male. Knowing the cause of the miscarriage does not reduce the risk of developing PTSD. Finding a 'meaning' for the loss reduces the risk of developing PTSD. A negative outlook regarding the world in general is corrlated with increased levels of PTSD. Poor self-esteem is also related to developing PTSD after the loss. If memories of the loss are considered intense, risk for PTSD is increased. There are concerns that PTSD in mothers may have a negative impact on children born after the event.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
Though the development of PTSD in women and families after the loss has been identified, the presence of PTSD in a woman who is pregnant is detrimental. Women with PTSD are thought to be at a higher risk of prenatal loss, perinatal loss, pregnancy complications, ectopic pregnancy, preterm birth and growth abnormalities in the fetus.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
PTSD in a mother is suspected to increase the risk of autism, hypertension, cardiovascular diseases, and type 2 diabetes in a child.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
==Depression and anxiety== 43% of women who miscarry are found to have depression, anxiety disorders, and obsessive-compulsive disorder.<ref name = rand/><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/880941778|title=Women's reproductive mental health across the lifespan|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Lynn-Barnes, Diana,|isbn=9783319051161|location=Cham|pages=|oclc=880941778 |postscript = (online text, no page numbers)|last1=Barnes|first1=Diana Lynn|date=2014-05-30}}</ref> <!--and [[bipolar disorder]].{{mcn|date=October 2017}} [[ Impact of Event Scale - Revised (IES-R)]] has been used to quantify the severity of a miscarriage and 47.5% of the women experiencing a miscarriage have high scores. Follow-up determined that even after 2 years, 2.6% of women still have high impact scores.{{mcn|date=October 2017}}-->
[[Prolonged grief disorder|Complicated grief]] is an [[Atypical depression|atypical]] response to a miscarriage. It differs from the more common form of [[Miscarriage and grief|grief]] that occurs after a miscarriage. The [[Kübler-Ross model|grieving process]] associated with other events such as the loss of a spouse or parent is expected to decline in a predictable and steady rate. This not true for those experiencing grief after a miscarriage because only 41% follow the expected decline in grief while most (59%) do not fit this pattern.<ref name = kirs/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/2012/06/miscarriage.aspx|title=Miscarriage and loss|publisher = American Psychological Association | date = 2017 |language=en|access-date=2017-09-23}}</ref>
[[Cognitive behavioral therapy|Cognitive Behavior Therapy]] has been found to be helpful if it is begun immediately after the loss.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
== Epidemeology == A woman who miscarries has a 2.5 times greater risk for depression than those who have not.<ref name=":0" /> In the US, estimates of PTSD related to miscarriage are thought to be 150,000–200,000 acute and 24,000–32,000 chronic PTSD cases. PTSD in fathers may be significant but remains unaddressed.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * {{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/153919942|title=Grief unseen : healing pregnancy loss through the arts|last=Seftel|first=Laura|date=2006|publisher=Jessica Kingsley Publishers|year=|isbn=9781843108054|location=London|pages=|oclc=153919942}} *{{cite book | last = Martin | first = Colin | title = Perinatal Mental Health : a Clinical Guide | publisher = M & K Pub | location = Cumbria England | year = 2012 | isbn = 9781907830495 }}
